items.title: Masonry moves forward
items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹661 â€” September 25, 2024 | Read on the web

The First Public Working Draft of CSS Grid Level 3 / Masonry Layout â€” This new draft represents progress on masonry layout as a built-in capability of CSS in two possible syntactic forms: a grid-integrated syntax, and a grid-independent syntax, both outlined asÂ alternatives. The CSSWG has resolved to adopt fully mixed track sizing for this new layout model, allowing all the possible track listings expressible in CSS Grid for masonry layouts too.

W3C

â–¶Â Â CSS Masonry Layouts â€” As weâ€™ve covered in recent months (and as alluded to above) thereâ€™s differing, strong opinions on how best masonry layouts should finally be realised in CSS. Nicole does a good job of bringing us up to speed on the various sides both clearly andÂ fairly.

Nicole Sullivan

ğŸ’¬ Related: Rachel Andrew makes the case for a separate display: masonry value.

How To Make Your Web Page Faster Before It Even Loads â€” What about the events that happen before the first byte of a web page is received by the browser? Read from Salma Alam-Naylor, how to measure those events and optimize them to make web pages and applications load evenÂ faster.

Sentry sponsor

How Josh W. Comeau Rebuilt His Blog, App Router Style â€” Weâ€™re huge fans of Joshâ€™s blog (particularly its wealth of CSS articles). Heâ€™s just rebuilt it entirely using Next.js, MDX, Sandpack, and an array of other technologies, and gives a detailed, behind the scenes look at a modern React-driven frontendÂ project.

Josh W Comeau

Get Ready for Interop 2025: Your Chance to Shape the Web â€” An invite to â€œhelp shape the future of web interoperabilityâ€. Submissions for ideas/proposals are being taken now, with the deadline on October 9th. Hereâ€™s what 2024 has focusedÂ on.

Nicole Sullivan

âš¡ï¸ Quick Links

  • ğŸ”¥ There's drama in the WordPressâ„¢ world, with Matt Mullenwag sharing his beef with WPEngine. WPEngine has sent a cease and desist in response.

  • ğŸ“µ California Govenor Newsom has vetoed a bill that would have required makers of browsers and mobile OS's to let consumers set user data opt-out preferences.

  • â˜ï¸ Cloudflare now allows you to block all LLM crawler bots.

  • ğŸ¦Š Here's what's new in Firefox DevTools 130.

  • ğŸ˜† Alvaro Montoro has some bad CSS 'Dad jokes' to share.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Improving Rendering Performance with CSS content-visibility â€” When a page has 20,000 custom emoji on it, things may well get a touch slow. Nolan set out to fixÂ things.

Nolan Lawson

A Redesign Case Study â€” Like Josh Comeau (above), Ahmad Shadeed, whose excellent frontend articles we often feature, has too recently rebuilt his website, though with a stronger focus on the design. This case study digs into his rationale andÂ process.

Ahmad Shadeed

AI for Front-End Devs: Faster Code Reviews, Fewer Bugs â€” Streamline your front-end code reviews with AI-driven insights. Improve UI, performance, and code qualityÂ faster.

CodeRabbit sponsor

The Frontend Treadmill â€” Some candid advice and musings on the frontend ecosystem, technical decisions, and wasted energies: â€œour current framework layer is working against the grain instead of embracing theÂ platformâ€.

Marco Rogers

Monitor Your Local and Real-User Core Web Vitals Performance in Chrome 129 â€” The latest Chrome features a completely redesigned Performance panel landing page featuring a live view of your local Core Web VitalsÂ performance.

Rick Viscomi

How to Create a Chrome Extension with React, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS and Vite â€” Covers everything you need to know right through to publishing in the Chrome WebÂ Store.

Lokman Musliu

Clever Polypane Debugging Features I'm Loving â€” A nice look at some of the handy features to be found in the stand-alone dev browser, Polypane.

Ryan Trimble

Mobile Accessibility Testing: Enhancing User Experience for All
Caitlin de Rooij

How to Defer Offscreen Images and Background Images
Anna Monus

â–¶Â Â The Easy Way to Understand Flexbox Alignment
Kevin Powell

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Dark Patterns Hall of Shame: Learn About Dark Patterns and Unethical Designs â€” Real examples showcasing what not to do in UI design, with details/screenshots from real websites that have made such poor UIÂ choices.

Dark Patterns Hall of Shame

CSS Almanac â€” The almanac over at CSS Tricks has been spruced up. Itâ€™s a great resource packed with references for various CSS selectors andÂ properties.

Geoff Graham

Generate Dynamic JSON Forms and Collect Data Right in YourÂ App â€” Integrate SurveyJS UI libraries to design secure, custom forms in minutes. Code-free interface, easy integration with any backend, and fullyÂ customizable.

SurveyJS sponsor

Vue-Multiselect 3.1: A Complete 'Selecting Solution' for Vue.js â€” Thereâ€™s a lot on offer here, complete with SSR support, Vuex support, strong test coverage, and with noÂ dependencies.

Damian Dulisz et al.

Departure Mono: Monospace Pixel Font with a Lo-Fi TechnicalÂ Vibe â€” Itâ€™s open source and takes inspiration from â€œthe constraints of early command-line and graphical user interfacesâ€, along with late 90s and early 2000s pixel fonts. CoolÂ website!

Tobias Fried

blocks.md: Generate Forms and Web Pages from Markdown â€” Not a free tool, but an interesting one to try out. It has its own syntax along the lines of something like Haml or Pug, and you can use it freeÂ locally.

blocks.md

ğŸ•°ï¸ ICYMI (Older links, still worth checking out)

  • Salma Alam-Naylor digs into the 'Largest Contentful Paint' (LCP) metric and how a bad score "might be a backend issue".

  • Vitaly Friedman shares practical techniques on how to get buy-in for accessibilityÂ efforts.

  • ...and finally Brecht De Ruyte runs through what you need to know about CSS Anchor Positioning.

Ipx.

items.title: New iOS, new macOS, so there's a new Safari, too.
items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹660 â€” September 18, 2024 | Read on the web

WebKit Features in Safari 18.0 â€” Safari 18 arrives alongside iOS 18 and macOS Sequoia, along with 53 new web platform features. This new version of Appleâ€™s browser has some interesting features, such as the ability to hide â€˜distractingâ€™ items from a web page, new iPhone Mirroring and remote inspection options, and it joins Chrome in supporting View Transitions and Style Queries when testing CSS CustomÂ Properties.

Jen Simmons

Optimizing for High Latency Environments â€” If youâ€™ve a particular interest or responsibility in diving deep into performance metrics, then this detailed post from Harry on round-trip-time (RTT) should proveÂ invaluable.

Harry Roberts

WorkOS: Start Selling to Enterprises with Just a Few Lines of Code â€” WorkOS is a modern identity platform for B2B SaaS. It provides flexible and easy-to-use APIs to integrate SSO, SCIM, and RBAC in minutes. WorkOS is used by hundreds of high-growth startups including Perplexity, Vercel, Drata, &Â Webflow.

WorkOS sponsor

'In 2024, Just 0.5% of the Global Top 200 Websites Use Valid HTML' â€” Jens digs into some of the rather woeful findings from the latest HTML conformance data and urges us to ship validÂ HTML.

Jens Oliver Meiert

Astro 5.0 Beta Release â€” The first beta release of Astro 5.0, the popular web framework is now available. This new release includes the now stable Astro Content Layer, along with stable server islands, a new way to mix static and personalizedÂ content.

Astro

âš¡ï¸ Quick Links

  • ğŸ”— Google Search now links directly to the Internet Archive for accessing older versions of Web pages â€“ this replaces Google's 'cached' pageÂ feature.

  • â„¢ï¸ Isn't it about time Oracle gave up the JavaScript trademark?

  • âœï¸ The latest working draft of the CSS Values and Units Module document has been published.

  • ğŸˆ Static site generator 11ty is joining Font Awesome in a partnership that will "extend the life expectancy of the project".

  • ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§ As someone based in the United Kingdom, this common country selector dropdown issue is veryÂ relatable.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

â–¶Â Â The â€œOtherâ€ C in CSS â€” A practical, technical hour-long talk from this year's CSS Day conference about accessibility, and how CSS affects the semantic accessibility of ourÂ HTML.

Sara Soueidan

ğŸ’¬ Another talk from CSS Day recently put on YouTube is this presentation from Josh Comeau on how to teach CSS, focusing on some of the mental models and analogies that help make CSS click.

How to Animate to height: auto (and Other Intrinsic Sizing Keywords) â€” An often requested CSS feature is the ability to animate to height: auto and CSSâ€™s interpolate-size property and the calc-size() function provide a way to do this, though itâ€™s limited to Chrome 129+ forÂ now.

Bramus (Chrome)

Streamline Your Product Delivery with monday dev â€” From ideation to launch, monday dev makes product delivery faster and simpler, all in oneÂ place.

monday dev sponsor

The State of ES5 on the Web â€” Early JavaScript build tools often focused on allowing modern features to be used on the Web at the time by compiling down to ES5 code that could run anywhere. Time has moved on, but have the tools or popular libraries? Philip investigates, and shares someÂ recommendations.

Philip Walton

Logical Properties in Size Queries â€” â€œWe may need size-based media queries for some time yet, and being able to use logical properties with them would certainly beÂ usefulâ€.

Michelle Barker

ğŸ˜¢Â The Continuing Tragedy of Emoji on the Web â€” Nolan laments â€œhow half-heartedly browsers and operating systems have worked to keep their emoji up toÂ dateâ€.

Nolan Lawson

Two CSS Properties for Trimming Text Box Whitespace â€” Specifically, text-box-trim and text-box-edge, two fine-grain properties to trim specific amounts of whitespace aroundÂ text. Support is limited, and only behind a feature flag for now.

Daniel Schwarz

Letâ€™s Bring Back Browsing â€” â€œTo â€œsurf the webâ€ implied fun and adventure and to â€œbrowseâ€ implied serendipity. And we seem to have lost that. Letâ€™s goÂ backâ€.

Christian Heilmann

A Step-by-Step Guide to Conducting a Web Accessibility Audit
Melissa Morse

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

The First HTML LSP That Reports Syntax Errors â€” A new Language Server for HTML that catches various syntax errors (either in popular editors such as VSCode or as a CLI tool). It claims to deliver immediate feedback on HTML errors, and commonÂ typos.

Loris Cro

Run GitHub Actions Up to 2x Faster at Half the Cost â€” Blacksmith runs GitHub Actions up to 2x faster at half the cost. Trusted by 100+ companies like Ashby andÂ Slope.

Blacksmith sponsor

@bramus/caniuse-cli: A CLI Tool for â€œCan I Useâ€ â€” Bramus has built an (offline) command line tool for the always useful Can I Use and MDNâ€™s browser-compat-data. The npm package is here. Once installed, use caniuse at the command line to query. Handy!

Bramus Van Damme

DECK.GL: GPU-Powered Large-Scale Data Visualization Framework â€” Particularly well suited to geospatial data visualization use cases that go beyond typical 2D views. There are plenty of examples to show you what it can do. Can be used through both vanilla JS and ReactÂ interfaces.

OpenJS Foundation

Free Public APIs: A Collection of Free Public APIs for Developers â€” Categorized and searchable, these are tested daily via bots so if any API is taken down or moved behind a paywall, it gets removed from theÂ site.

Nick Schneeberger

AIEditor: A Next-Generation Rich Text Editor with AI Features â€” Based on Web Components so it can be integrated with any framework, has real-time collab, Markdown-friendly, and includes AI capabilities like spelling/grammar checks, one-click translation, andÂ more. (LGPL licensed with a 'pro'Â option.)

AIEditor

11ty-Serene: A Minimal Landing Page Theme for Eleventy â€” Styled with Tailwind and includes scroll-revealÂ effects. (Eleventy / 11ty is a popular Node.js-powered static site generator.)

Kevin Zhong

Dev Utilities: A Suite of Free, Open Source, Ad-Free Tools for Developers
jam

Slimify: Fast and Lossless Image Compression for JPEG, PNG, and WebP
Slimify

ğŸ•°ï¸ ICYMI (Older links, still worth checking out)

  • This one is something of an golden oldie â€”Â Robin Rendle explains how rem and em are useful for different jobs, and how we can use them both for extra maintainability and flexibility.

  • Hossein Yazdi brings together a collection of 20 'super useful' CSS animationÂ libraries.

  • Here's how to get the width/height of any element with only CSS.

  • Curious as to which page elements are considered/contribute to the Interaction to Next Paint (INP) metric? Umar Hansa explores what we need to know.

Ipx.

items.title: 'Release notes' for the entire web platform?
items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹659 â€” September 11, 2024 | Read on the web

CSS Display Contents â€” Ahmad takes a a look at how best to use 'display: contents' in order to build more fluid layouts. As ever with Ahmadâ€™s work, there are plenty of code examples and use cases to help ourÂ understanding.

Ahmad Shadeed

The Undeniable Utility of CSS :has â€” Josh has spent the past few months rebuilding his blog using modern CSS techniques, including the :has pseudo-class. Here he reflects on just how useful it is by way of some real-world use cases and some â€˜mindblowingâ€™ experiments.

Josh W. Comeau

The Frontend Masters Knowledge Quest Sale Is Going on All Week! â€” The Frontend Masters Knowledge Quest sale is now on! There's four new learning paths (including JS performance and code architecture) with more epic courses on the way throughout 2024 andÂ beyond.

Frontend Masters sponsor

CSS Triggers â€” If you want to write more performant CSS, then understanding how things are rendered (layout, paint, and composite) across the three main browser engines is always going to be handy knowledge. This site brings together findings across a series of CSSÂ properties.

Andrico Karoulla

A Complete Guide to Beginning with JavaScript â€” A rather epic article packed with background knowledge, context, and third party resources for starting a modern JavaScript learningÂ journey.

Cody Lindley

âš¡ï¸ Quick Links

  • ğŸ”  Modern Web fonts have many more features available within them than you mightÂ expect..

  • ğŸ¤– /llms.txt is a proposed file that sites could provide for large language models to better use a site's features at inferenceÂ time.

  • ğŸ˜µ Firefox is joining other browsers in finally 'unshipping' HTTP/2 Push support.

  • ğŸ› ï¸ Is immediately jumping for added tooling just a form of premature optimization when it comes to building WebÂ sites?

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Sticky Headers and Full-Height Elements: A Tricky Combination â€” Philip warns that sticky elements often donâ€™t play nicely if they have to coordinate with other elements to make up a combined height (such as 100vh). This post explores why this happens and offers up aÂ solution.

Philip Braunen

Brand New Performance Features in Chrome DevTools â€” A helpful look into Chromeâ€™s updated Performance Panel and all the different metrics it shows off to help you improve the performance of yourÂ site.

Umar Hansa (DebugBear)

[Workshop] Fix Your Front-End: JavaScript Edition â€” Learn practical tips to make debugging more tolerable. Join our JavaScript team live for a masterclass on SeptÂ 24.

Sentry sponsor

Anchor Positioning Quirks â€” Dives into the various potential â€˜head-scratchersâ€™ that you may come up against when working with anchor positioning, breaking them down so youâ€™ll hopefully have an easier time when you come to useÂ them.

Juan Diego RodrÃ­guez

A Release Note for the Web Platform â€” Details of a community-driven effort to create an index of all features across the entire web platform, which will track their availability, and share the latest information via releaseÂ notes.

Patrick Brosset

The Web's Clipboard, and How It Stores Data of Different Types â€” An interesting exploration of how things currently work with copy and pasting on the web, how different data types are treated, and what the Web Custom Formats proposal is puttingÂ forward.

Alex Harri JÃ³nsson

Simplify Data Collection with a Fully Integrated Custom FormÂ Builder â€” Build dynamic JSON-driven front-end forms of any complexity directly within your app. Integrate with any backend system. Drag-and-dropÂ UI.

SurveyJS sponsor

Time Travelling CSS with :target â€” A fun look at how you can achieve a kind of â€˜primitive version of client-side routingâ€™ solely through the behavior of :target. A fun one.

Lee Mayer

â¬› Â Alternatives to Using Pure Black (#000000) for Text and Backgrounds
Dmitry Sergushkin

From Parcel to Vite: A Short Story of a 100K LOC Migration
Gao / Logto

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

svg.wtf: An SVG Playground to Learn How to Write SVG Code â€” Includes some useful code-related features like tooltip info on hover, to help understand the different elements, attributes, etc.

Amelia Wattenberger

Redirect Checker: A URL Redirect Analysis Tool â€” Includes numerous features to help analyze your redirects, like providing a detailed path analysis, bulk redirect checking, custom user-agent selection, amongÂ others.

Sead Feng

ğŸ“± Â Web Inspector: An iOS/iPadOS App to Expand Mobile Safari with Extra Development Tools â€” Similar to a desktop browserâ€™s DevTools, this lets you inspect elements, edit styles, run commands in a console, view network requests, andÂ more.

And a Dinosaur

ğŸ“° Classifieds

Blacksmith runs GitHub Actions up to 2x faster at half the cost with a one-line change. Trusted by 100+ companies like Ashby andÂ Slope.

SVGEdit: A Powerful Browser-Based SVG Editor â€” A fast, web-based, JavaScript-driven SVG drawing editor that works in any modern browser. You can try it live here or host it forÂ yourself.

SVG-Edit Authors

ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§ Â GOV.UK Vue: Build Vue Apps, the British Way â€” The UK government is well known for providing its citizens with an effective, well designed Web site for performing various civic tasks. Now you can get all of their clean components in Vue 3Â form.

UK Government

Open Graph Generator: A Free Tool to Create Meta Tags for Your Pages
Open Graph Generator

StatiCrypt 3.5: Password Protect a Static HTML Page
Robin Moisson

Ninja Backgrounds: Customizable Pure CSS Backgrounds Made with Bootstrap 5
NinjaBootstrap

Ipx.
items.contentSnippet:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus


            
#â€‹659 â€” September 11, 2024 | Read on the web

          
        



  





  
  
CSS Display Contents â€” Ahmad takes a a look at how best to use 'display: contents' in order to build more fluid layouts. As ever with Ahmadâ€™s work, there are plenty of code examples and use cases to help ourÂ understanding.
Ahmad Shadeed 


  
  
The Undeniable Utility of CSS :has â€” Josh has spent the past few months rebuilding his blog using modern CSS techniques, including the :has pseudo-class. Here he reflects on just how useful it is by way of some real-world use cases and some â€˜mindblowingâ€™ experiments.
Josh W. Comeau 


  
  
The Frontend Masters Knowledge Quest Sale Is Going on All Week! â€” The Frontend Masters Knowledge Quest sale is now on! There's four new learning paths (including JS performance and code architecture) with more epic courses on the way throughout 2024 andÂ beyond.
Frontend Masters sponsor


  
  
CSS Triggers â€” If you want to write more performant CSS, then understanding how things are rendered (layout, paint, and composite) across the three main browser engines is always going to be handy knowledge. This site brings together findings across a series of CSSÂ properties.
Andrico Karoulla 


  
  
A Complete Guide to Beginning with JavaScript â€” A rather epic article packed with background knowledge, context, and third party resources for starting a modern JavaScript learningÂ journey.
Cody Lindley 







âš¡ï¸ Quick Links
ğŸ”  Modern Web fonts have many more features available within them than you mightÂ expect..
ğŸ¤– /llms.txt is a proposed file that sites could provide for large language models to better use a site's features at inferenceÂ time.
ğŸ˜µ Firefox is joining other browsers in finally 'unshipping' HTTP/2 Push support.
ğŸ› ï¸ Is immediately jumping for added tooling just a form of premature optimization when it comes to building WebÂ sites?










ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion





  
  
Sticky Headers and Full-Height Elements: A Tricky Combination â€” Philip warns that sticky elements often donâ€™t play nicely if they have to coordinate with other elements to make up a combined height (such as 100vh). This post explores why this happens and offers up aÂ solution.
Philip Braunen 


  
  
Brand New Performance Features in Chrome DevTools â€” A helpful look into Chromeâ€™s updated Performance Panel and all the different metrics it shows off to help you improve the performance of yourÂ site.
Umar Hansa (DebugBear) 


  
  
[Workshop] Fix Your Front-End: JavaScript Edition â€” Learn practical tips to make debugging more tolerable. Join our JavaScript team live for a masterclass on SeptÂ 24.
Sentry sponsor


  
  
Anchor Positioning Quirks â€” Dives into the various potential â€˜head-scratchersâ€™ that you may come up against when working with anchor positioning, breaking them down so youâ€™ll hopefully have an easier time when you come to useÂ them.
Juan Diego RodrÃ­guez 


  
  
A Release Note for the Web Platform â€” Details of a community-driven effort to create an index of all features across the entire web platform, which will track their availability, and share the latest information via releaseÂ notes.
Patrick Brosset 


  
  
The Web's Clipboard, and How It Stores Data of Different Types â€” An interesting exploration of how things currently work with copy and pasting on the web, how different data types are treated, and what the Web Custom Formats proposal is puttingÂ forward.

Simplify Data Collection with a Fully Integrated Custom FormÂ Builder â€” Build dynamic JSON-driven front-end forms of any complexity directly within your app. Integrate with any backend system. Drag-and-dropÂ UI.
SurveyJS sponsor


  
  
Time Travelling CSS with :target â€” A fun look at how you can achieve a kind of â€˜primitive version of client-side routingâ€™ solely through the behavior of :target. A fun one.
Lee Mayer 


  
â¬› Â Alternatives to Using Pure Black (#000000) for Text and Backgrounds
  
Dmitry Sergushkin 
  


  
From Parcel to Vite: A Short Story of a 100K LOC Migration
  
Gao / Logto 
  





ğŸ”§  Code, Tools & Resources




  





  
  
svg.wtf: An SVG Playground to Learn How to Write SVG Code â€” Includes some useful code-related features like tooltip info on hover, to help understand the different elements, attributes, etc.
Amelia Wattenberger 


  
  
Redirect Checker: A URL Redirect Analysis Tool â€” Includes numerous features to help analyze your redirects, like providing a detailed path analysis, bulk redirect checking, custom user-agent selection, amongÂ others.
Sead Feng 


  
  
ğŸ“± Â Web Inspector: An iOS/iPadOS App to Expand Mobile Safari with Extra Development Tools â€” Similar to a desktop browserâ€™s DevTools, this lets you inspect elements, edit styles, run commands in a console, view network requests, andÂ more.
And a Dinosaur 












ğŸ“° Classifieds

  



Blacksmith runs GitHub Actions up to 2x faster at half the cost with a one-line change. Trusted by 100+ companies like Ashby andÂ Slope.







  
  
SVGEdit: A Powerful Browser-Based SVG Editor â€” A fast, web-based, JavaScript-driven SVG drawing editor that works in any modern browser. You can try it live here or host it forÂ yourself.

items.title: Remembering the first decade of web design
items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹658 â€” September 4, 2024 | Read on the web

The Secret Inside One Million Checkboxes â€” One Million Checkboxes is/was a site with one million global checkboxes on it where checking (or unchecking) a box changed it for everyone on the site, instantly. This fun post-mortem digs into how the internet (and, specifically, a group of smart teenagers) played with the project to reach ends you'd neverÂ expect..

Nolen

The Ultimate Guide to Font Performance Optimization â€” This is quite the rabbit hole indeed, but a useful one to go down if your site is using custom fonts and youâ€™re serving them up directly yourself. Of course, step one is to consider sticking to system/web-safe fonts.. ;-)

Anna Monus (DebugBear)

Beyond the 10x Engineer â€” Incredible technical skills canâ€™t save a product that no one wants. Thatâ€™s why engineers should care about non-technical product skills. To help you figure out which of these skills matter, we wrote about the ones we look for (and use) atÂ PostHog.

PostHog sponsor

Supporting AVIF in Google Search â€” Image format AVIF is now a supported file type in Google Search and Google Images, as well as any place that uses images in GoogleÂ Search.

John Mueller (Google)

The Web Design Museum: The First Decade of Web Design â€” Exhibits thousands of unique old website designs from the early 90s to mid-00s. A fun way to discover forgotten trends in webÂ design.

Web Design Museum

Apple 'Appears to Mislead' UK Regulator Over Deceptive Default Browser User Interface â€” Looks like Apple is claiming that a previously implemented pattern for picking default browsers in iOS, in fact, never even existed. ğŸ˜µâ€ğŸ’«

Open Web Advocacy

âš¡ï¸ Quick Links

  • âœ¨ Rachel Andrew from the Chrome team brings us a recent round-up of all that's new to the web platform.

  • â†”ï¸ Firefox 130 adds WebDriver BiDi updates, including browsingContext.navigationFailed event support.

  • âŒ¨ï¸ Server Mono is a neat monospace font inspired by typewriters, ASCII art, and command-line interfaces.

  • ğŸ—³ï¸ ICYMI, the 2024 State of CSS survey is now open and seeking your input.

  • ğŸª² Chrome's bug bounty is now up to $250,000.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

â–¶Â Â Caching Demystified: Inspect, Clear, and Disable Caches â€” Dives into the different types of browser cache and how to inspect and manage them in ChromeÂ DevTools.

Jecelyn Yeen

Finding Two Lines of CSS That Tanked Performance â€” Upon launching the Learn Web Components site, Andrico discovered one of its animations caused a sharp drop in performance on Firefox. Hereâ€™s what he discovered and how he fixedÂ it.

Andrico Karoulla

ğŸ’¡ Andrico has also written about how he improved the screen reader experience for visitors toÂ LearnÂ WCs.

ğŸ—“ï¸Â Join us at ViteConf! â€” On October 3rd & 4th, get ready to learn from the builders pushing modern web development forward. Donâ€™t miss outâ€”get your ticketÂ now!

StackBlitz sponsor

Lazy Loading Isn't Just Lazy, It's Late: We Can Do Better â€” â€œWe tend only to fetch more content as the user scrolls it into view or navigates to the next page, which isnâ€™t just lazy: itâ€™s often late and an awful user experienceâ€. This post suggests a more proactiveÂ approach.

Jupiter Jayna

â–¶Â Â Scroll-Enhanced Experiences â€” A 52-minute journey through the art of 'scrollytelling' with CSS, guiding you through the process of creating dynamic experiences that leverage a userâ€™s scroll behavior. Covers controlling pace/rhythm of a page with the CSS Scroll TimelineÂ API.

Carmen Ansio

'Why I Donâ€™t Block AI Scrapers' â€” â€œlet thieves do thief things until our justice system(s) do justice systemÂ thingsâ€.

Jens Oliver Meiert

How to Quickly (and Weightlessly) Convert Chrome Extensions to Safari â€” Goes into more depth than you mightÂ expect.
Nina Torgunakova

Five HTML Features Youâ€™re Not Using (But Should Be)
Safdar Ali

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Reasonable Colors: An Open-Source Color System for Building Beautiful, Accessible Color Palettes â€” Just drop in the base stylesheet, then use the provided CSS variables that provide built-in â€œshadesâ€ for eachÂ color.

matthew howell

Introducing style-observer, A MutationObserver for CSS â€” Bramus has created a MutationObserver for CSS. It, dubbed style-observer, allows you to attach JavaScript callbacks to changes in computed values of CSSÂ properties.

Bramus Van Damme

Passkeys for Everyone! Make Your User Login Simpler with FusionAuth â€” FusionAuth just added passkeys to their free tier, which is a paid feature for almost every other auth provider. Try it outÂ yourself.

FusionAuth sponsor

The Dev Tools Performance Monitor Panel â€” In Chrome, if you open 'Dev Tools > More Tools > Performance Monitor' youâ€™ll see some helpful high-level charts and graphs of the realtime performance data of yourÂ UI.

Dave Rupert

Avatars: A Collection of Diverse Free Avatar Images â€” Downloadable in PNG format, but also accessible directly via a public CDN and thereâ€™s a Figma pluginÂ available.

alohe

Tailwind Grid Builder: Learn and Build CSS Grids with Tailwind â€” A simple tool to generate the HTML with Tailwind classes for a custom grid. Just select number of items, rows, columns, and number of breakpoints as needed. Useful also for learning the Tailwind classÂ names.

Tailscan

ğŸ And one for fun..

Button Stealer: A Chrome Extension That "Steals" a Button from Every Website You Open â€” A funny way of 'collecting' an inspiration gallery of buttons, which the author has done and you can viewÂ here.

anatoly zenkov

Ipx.

title: Frontend Focus
description: A onceâ€“weekly roundup of the best front-end news, articles and tutorials. HTML, CSS, WebGL, Canvas, browser tech, and more.
